text:
STEPHANIE ELAM: This gold box
in the middle of a Los Angeles
park is a portal to the world.

- And when you enter
it, you feel like you're

in the same room as someone in
an identical shipping container
somewhere else on earth.

ARI SAPERSTEIN: How did
you learn English so well?

- From school and
from Justin Bieber.

ARI SAPERSTEIN: I'll go home
and listen to a little Justin
Bieber in a new light now.

AMAR BAKSHI: We started about 2
and 1/2 years ago between Iran
and the US, as a park project.

And it's grown from
Mexico to Rwanda
to Germany to Afghanistan.

STEPHANIE ELAM: This LA portal
is connected to a refugee
camp in Erbil, Iraq.
My name is Stephanie.
- Nice to meet you.
My name's Rami.

AMAR BAKSHI: I don't
expect everyone to like
or agree with each other.

But at least they
should recognize
the diversity of human beings.

- I learn from this portal
that American people
are very amazing people.

They want to make
space around the world.

STEPHANIE ELAM: Which
two people, do you think,

could use this portal that
might actually help us
understand each other better?

- The people who are
in the governments,

in other countries
around the world,

like Trump or other presidents,
should come in the portal.

STEPHANIE ELAM: So far there
are two dozen permanent portals
around the world.

AMAR BAKSHI: We're working
from setting one up in a prison

to in Liberia outside
of a hospital.

ARI SAPERSTEIN: We
can use it to create
something beautiful and good.
[foreign language]
